So I am pretty good at talking to strangers and stuff and what I find most is people will talk about themselves none stop and rarely ask you anything back (if they do you have found yourself a great person). So for me I just keep asking them questions about everything and anything generic and when they answer I ask more questions on their answers. Most people won't realise that they are not even asking you anything back. This works to help keep a convo up with a stranger, normally when I find someone more likely to be a friend we have an equal convo but hey sometimes it's just about getting through the awkwardness

My Great-Grandad on my mums side was from Dublin and fought at the Somme-got his tongue shot out I never met him. My great great uncle on my dads side was Sean McDermott who planned the Eater Rising and was executed for doing so. Ireland is interesting in this respect. Both sides, North and South joined up quickly into the war (remember their was nearly a civil war in Ireland just before WW1) and the IRB weren't actually that popular when they carried out the Easter Rising. Anyway an interesting piece of Irish history and cool my different relatives were on different sides

WRITING.TITLE: Do multiplayer 'packs' turn people off a game for good?
WRITING.TEXT: So I absolutely hate the new packs system that has made its way into every multiplayer game. The only game it's kinda makes sense in are the EA sports games as they are sort of like sports trading cards. But this system has absolutely ruined multiplayer in two of my favourite franchises - Halo and Gears. Why is the whole fucking multiplayer designed around getting these bullshit packs? It makes the whole thing feel overcomplicated and stupid. I shouldn't have to get a Halo vehicle in a fucking pack I could pay money for. I shouldn't have to unlock/buy packs for every skin. I don't have a huge problem with some micro transactions (I love BF1 but the stuff they are selling is so pointless) but when you design the entire multiplayer in getting more money from players who already bought you game it's puts me off. Never enjoyed Halo 5 and Gears 4 the way I did in previous entries

WRITING.TITLE: Daredevil is a good show period. Iron Fist is a bad superhero show and even worse 'show' overall.
WRITING.TEXT:
I think what makes Daredevil stand out for me in terms of the genre is that it's a good show on its own. Most of the non-superhero aspects are really well done and interesting (Matt and Foggy lawyering, Karen being a journalist, the trial of Frank etc). This is on top of the fight scenes being some of the best I've ever seen (movies and tv) and the genuine superhero stories being great (Frank Vs DD, Stick, Elektra and Matt vs the Hand) and yes I really love season 2 even though I know many are mixed. Where Iron Fist fails is that all the boardroom stuff is so dull and because he doesn't have a secret identity it's hampers the actual superhero stuff. Iron Fist had some good stuff with the Hand too up until episode 7, then it got even worse. There are no likeable characters apart from Coleen and you don't really care what happens to any of them.
I think someone said Iron Fist might have been a good show maybe 10+ years ago but now the standard is way to high for something like that to be seen as good. Rewatching DareDevil S1 now and the difference is amazing. Matt is way more interesting, likeable and cool than Danny. I feel DD has changed what a superhero show can be. Jon Bethnal's performance as Frank was seriously Emmy worthy but obviously it could ignored because it was in a marvel property.

SS-GB is incredibly grounded and I think the BBC always hire great writers for period dramas. Man in the High Castle is abit more Hollywood so yeah some of it is more over the top I think more catered to an American audience (you could never make an Archer type character work in this world) anyway I sill like it. Maybe just think of it as historical science fiction more than anything else? I don't feel it's meant to be that realistic although they have made a convincing world
